docs.title: ScalarUdfImpl
docs.text:
Scalar user-defined function wrapper

This class is a wrapper class used as the return value for user-defined function constructors. This wrapper allows the UDF to be registered with a SedonaDB context or any context that accepts DataFusion Python Scalar UDFs. This object is not intended to be used to call a UDF.

docs.title: TypeMatcher
docs.text:
Bases: str

Helper class to mark type matchers that can be used as the input_types for user-defined functions

Note that the internal storage of the type matcher (currently a string) is arbitrary and may change in a future release. Use the constants provided by the udf module.

docs.title: arrow_udf
docs.text:
arrow_udf(
    return_type: Any,
    input_types: List[Union[TypeMatcher, Any]] = None,
    volatility: Literal["immutable", "stable", "volatile"] = "immutable",
    name: Optional[str] = None,
)

Generic Arrow-based user-defined scalar function decorator

This decorator may be used to annotate a function that accepts arguments as Arrow array wrappers implementing the Arrow PyCapsule Interface. The annotated function must return a value of a consistent length of the appropriate type.

Warning

SedonaDB will call the provided function from multiple threads. Attempts to modify shared state from the body of the function may crash or cause unusual behaviour.

SedonaDB Python UDFs are experimental and this interface may change based on user feedback.

Parameters:

  • return_type (Any) –

    One of - A data type (e.g., pyarrow.DataType, arro3.core.DataType, nanoarrow.Schema) if this function returns the same type regardless of its inputs. - A function of arg_types (list of data types) and scalar_args (list of optional scalars) that returns a data type. This function is also responsible for returning None if this function does not apply to the input types.

  • input_types (List[Union[TypeMatcher, Any]], default: None ) –

    One of - A list where each member is a data type or a TypeMatcher. The udf.GEOMETRY and udf.GEOGRAPHY type matchers are the most useful because otherwise the function will only match spatial data types whose coordinate reference system (CRS) also matches (i.e., based on simple equality). Using these type matchers will also ensure input CRS consistency and will automatically propagate input CRSes into the output. - None, indicating that this function can accept any number of arguments of any type. Usually this is paired with a functional return_type that dynamically computes a return type or returns None if the number or types of arguments do not match.

  • volatility (Literal['immutable', 'stable', 'volatile'], default: 'immutable' ) –

    Use "immutable" for functions whose output is always consistent for the same inputs (even between queries); use "stable" for functions whose output is always consistent for the same inputs but only within the same query, and use "volatile" for functions that generate random or otherwise non-deterministic output.

  • name (Optional[str], default: None ) –

    An optional name for the UDF. If not given, it will be derived from the name of the provided function.

Examples:

>>> import pyarrow as pa
>>> from sedonadb import udf
>>> sd = sedona.db.connect()

The simplest scalar UDF only specifies return types. This implies that
the function can handle input of any type.

>>> @udf.arrow_udf(pa.string())
... def some_udf(arg0, arg1):
...     arg0, arg1 = (
...         pa.array(arg0.to_array()).to_pylist(),
...         pa.array(arg1.to_array()).to_pylist(),
...     )
...     return pa.array(
...         (f"{item0} / {item1}" for item0, item1 in zip(arg0, arg1)),
...         pa.string(),
...     )
...
>>> sd.register_udf(some_udf)
>>> sd.sql("SELECT some_udf(123, 'abc') as col").show()
┌───────────┐
│    col    │
│    utf8   │
╞═══════════╡
│ 123 / abc │
└───────────┘

Use the `TypeMatcher` constants where possible to specify input.
This ensures that the function can handle the usual range of input
types that might exist for a given input.

>>> @udf.arrow_udf(pa.int64(), [udf.STRING])
... def char_count(arg0):
...     arg0 = pa.array(arg0.to_array())
...
...     return pa.array(
...         (len(item) for item in arg0.to_pylist()),
...         pa.int64()
...     )
...
>>> sd.register_udf(char_count)
>>> sd.sql("SELECT char_count('abcde') as col").show()
┌───────┐
│  col  │
│ int64 │
╞═══════╡
│     5 │
└───────┘

In this case, the type matcher ensures we can also use the function
for string view input which is the usual type SedonaDB emits when
reading Parquet files.

>>> sd.sql("SELECT char_count(arrow_cast('abcde', 'Utf8View')) as col").show()
┌───────┐
│  col  │
│ int64 │
╞═══════╡
│     5 │
└───────┘

Geometry UDFs are best written using Shapely because pyproj (including its use
in GeoPandas) is not thread safe and can crash when attempting to look up
CRSes when importing an Arrow array. The UDF framework supports returning
geometry storage to make this possible. Coordinate reference system metadata
is propagated automatically from the input.

>>> import shapely
>>> import geoarrow.pyarrow as ga
>>> @udf.arrow_udf(ga.wkb(), [udf.GEOMETRY, udf.NUMERIC])
... def shapely_udf(geom, distance):
...     geom_wkb = pa.array(geom.storage.to_array())
...     distance = pa.array(distance.to_array())
...     geom = shapely.from_wkb(geom_wkb)
...     result_shapely = shapely.buffer(geom, distance)
...     return pa.array(shapely.to_wkb(result_shapely))
...
>>>
>>> sd.register_udf(shapely_udf)
>>> sd.sql("SELECT ST_SRID(shapely_udf(ST_Point(0, 0), 2.0)) as col").show()
┌────────┐
│   col  │
│ uint32 │
╞════════╡
│      0 │
└────────┘

>>> sd.sql("SELECT ST_SRID(shapely_udf(ST_Point(0, 0, 3857), 2.0)) as col").show()
┌────────┐
│   col  │
│ uint32 │
╞════════╡
│   3857 │
└────────┘

Annotated functions may also declare keyword arguments `return_type` and/or `num_rows`,
which will be passed the appropriate value by the UDF framework. This facilitates writing
generic UDFs and/or UDFs with no arguments.

>>> import numpy as np
>>> def random_impl(return_type, num_rows):
...     pa_type = pa.field(return_type).type
...     return pa.array(np.random.random(num_rows), pa_type)
...
>>> @udf.arrow_udf(pa.float32(), [])
... def random_f32(*, return_type=None, num_rows=None):
...     return random_impl(return_type, num_rows)
...
>>> @udf.arrow_udf(pa.float64(), [])
... def random_f64(*, return_type=None, num_rows=None):
...     return random_impl(return_type, num_rows)
...
>>> np.random.seed(487)
>>> sd.register_udf(random_f32)
>>> sd.register_udf(random_f64)
>>> sd.sql("SELECT random_f32() AS f32, random_f64() as f64;").show()
┌────────────┬─────────────────────┐
│     f32    ┆         f64         │
│   float32  ┆       float64       │
╞════════════╪═════════════════════╡
│ 0.35385555 ┆ 0.24793247139474195 │
└────────────┴─────────────────────┘

docs.title: Spatial Joins
docs.text: You can perform spatial joins using standard SQL INNER JOIN syntax. The join condition is defined in the ON clause using a spatial function that specifies the relationship between the geometries of the two tables.

docs.title: General Spatial Join
docs.text: Use functions like ST_Contains, ST_Intersects, or ST_Within to join tables based on their spatial relationship.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
Assign a country to each city by checking which country polygon contains each city point.

SELECT
    cities.name as city,
    countries.name as country
FROM
    cities
INNER JOIN
    countries
    ON ST_Contains(countries.geometry, cities.geometry)

docs.title: K-Nearest Neighbor (KNN) Join
docs.text: Use the specialized ST_KNN function to find the k nearest neighbors from one table for each geometry in another. This is useful for proximity analysis.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
For each city, find the 5 other closest cities.

SELECT
    cities_l.name AS city,
    cities_r.name AS nearest_neighbor
FROM
    cities AS cities_l
INNER JOIN
    cities AS cities_r
    ON ST_KNN(cities_l.geometry, cities_r.geometry, 5, false)

docs.title: Optimization Barrier
docs.text:
Use the barrier function to prevent filter pushdown and control predicate evaluation order in complex spatial joins. This function creates an optimization barrier by evaluating boolean expressions at runtime.

The barrier function takes a boolean expression as a string, followed by pairs of variable names and their values that will be substituted into the expression:

barrier(expression, var_name1, var_value1, var_name2, var_value2, ...)

The placement of filters relative to KNN joins changes the semantic meaning of the query:

  • Filter before KNN: First filters the data, then finds K nearest neighbors from the filtered subset. This answers "What are the K nearest high-rated restaurants?"
  • Filter after KNN: First finds K nearest neighbors from all data, then filters those results. This answers "Of the K nearest restaurants, which ones are high-rated?"

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
Find the 3 nearest restaurants for each luxury hotel, and then filter the results to only show pairs where the restaurant is also high-rated.

SELECT
    h.name AS hotel,
    r.name AS restaurant,
    r.rating
FROM
    hotels AS h
INNER JOIN
    restaurants AS r
    ON ST_KNN(h.geometry, r.geometry, 3, false)
WHERE
    barrier('rating > 4.0 AND stars >= 4',
            'rating', r.rating,
            'stars', h.stars)

With the barrier function, this query first finds the 3 nearest restaurants to each hotel (regardless of rating), then filters to keep only those pairs where the restaurant has rating > 4.0 and the hotel has stars >= 4. Without the barrier, an optimizer might push the filters down, changing the query to first filter for high-rated restaurants and luxury hotels, then find the 3 nearest among those filtered sets.

docs.title: barrier
docs.text: Creates an optimization barrier that prevents filter pushdown by evaluating boolean expressions at runtime.

docs.title: Usage
docs.text: boolean barrier(expression: string, col_name: string, col_value: any)

docs.title: Description
docs.text:
barrier() evaluates a boolean expression string at runtime using bound column values, and is marked as volatile to prevent the query optimizer from reordering or pushing filters past it.

The first argument is a boolean expression string. After that, arguments come in pairs of (column_name, column_value) that bind variables used in the expression.

docs.title: Supported expression syntax
docs.text:
• Comparison operators: =, ==, !=, <>, >, >=, <, <=
  • Logical operators: AND / and, OR / or
  • Literal types: integers, floats, single- or double-quoted strings, true, false, null
  • Unrecognized expressions evaluate to false
  • NULL comparisons evaluate to false

docs.title: When to use
docs.text: Use barrier() when you need a predicate to be evaluated after a join or scan rather than being pushed down by the optimizer. This is useful when the predicate depends on values that are only available at a specific stage of query execution.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
Filter rows using bound column values:

SELECT *
FROM (VALUES (150, 'active'), (50, 'active'), (200, 'closed')) AS orders(amount, status)
WHERE barrier('amount > 100 AND status = "active"',
              'amount', amount,
              'status', status);

┌────────┬────────┐
│ amount ┆ status │
│  int64 ┆  utf8  │
╞════════╪════════╡
│    150 ┆ active │
└────────┴────────┘

Combine multiple conditions with different data types:

SELECT *
FROM (VALUES (29.99, 'electronics'), (9.99, 'books'), (49.99, 'electronics')) AS products(price, category)
WHERE barrier('price > 19.99 AND category = "electronics"',
              'price', price,
              'category', category);

┌─────────┬─────────────┐
│  price  ┆   category  │
│ float64 ┆     utf8    │
╞═════════╪═════════════╡
│   29.99 ┆ electronics │
├╌╌╌╌╌╌╌╌╌┼╌╌╌╌╌╌╌╌╌╌╌╌╌┤
│   49.99 ┆ electronics │
└─────────┴─────────────┘

Use OR logic:

SELECT *
FROM (VALUES (3, 'info'), (7, 'critical'), (10, 'warning')) AS events(priority, type)
WHERE barrier('priority < 5 OR type = "critical"',
              'priority', priority,
              'type', type);

┌──────────┬──────────┐
│ priority ┆   type   │
│   int64  ┆   utf8   │
╞══════════╪══════════╡
│        3 ┆ info     │
├╌╌╌╌╌╌╌╌╌╌┼╌╌╌╌╌╌╌╌╌╌┤
│        7 ┆ critical │
└──────────┴──────────┘

docs.title: ST_Analyze_Agg
docs.text: Computes the statistics of geometries for the input geometry.

docs.title: Description
docs.text:
ST_Analyze_Agg() provides a high-level summary of its input geometries. The fields of its struct return type are:

  • count: Number of input geometries
  • minx, miny, maxx, maxy: Minimum bounding rectangle (envelope)
  • mean_size_in_bytes
  • mean_points_per_geometry
  • puntal_count: Number of point or multipoint geometries
  • lineal_count: Number of line or multilinestring geometries
  • polygonal_count: Number of polygon or multipolygon geometries
  • geometrycollection_count: Number of geometrycollection geometries
  • mean_envelope_width
  • mean_envelope_height
  • mean_envelope_area

docs.title: Description
docs.text: ST_Area() Returns the area of a polygon or multi-polygon geometry.

docs.title: ST_AsBinary
docs.text: Converts a geometry to Well-Known Binary (WKB) format.

docs.title: Description
docs.text: ST_AsBinary() Returns the Well-Known Binary representation of a geometry or geography. This function also has the alias ST_AsWKB.

docs.title: ST_AsEWKB
docs.text: Returns the EWKB representation of a geometry or geography.

docs.title: Description
docs.text: EWKB extends WKB to include SRID information in the binary header and is useful for PostGIS compatibility. This function preserves item-level CRSes or will repeat a type-level CRS for all elements if present.

docs.title: ST_AsGeoJSON
docs.text: Returns the GeoJSON representation of a geometry.

docs.title: ST_AsText
docs.text: Returns the Well-Known Text string representation of a geometry or geography.

docs.title: ST_Azimuth
docs.text: Returns the azimuth between two points in radians, or NULL if not available.

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Returns the azimuth (angle) from the first point to the second point, measured in radians clockwise from north. Returns NULL if either input is not a point.

docs.title: ST_Boundary
docs.text: Returns the closure of the combinatorial boundary of this Geometry.

docs.title: Description
docs.text: For a polygon, the boundary is the exterior and interior rings; for a linestring it is the endpoints.

docs.title: ST_Buffer
docs.text: Computes a geometry that represents all points whose distance from the input geometry is less than or equal to a specified distance.

docs.title: Usage
docs.text:
geometry ST_Buffer(geom: geometry, distance: float64)
geometry ST_Buffer(geom: geometry, distance: float64, params: string)

docs.title: Arguments
docs.text:
• geom (geometry): Input geometry
  • distance (float64): Radius of the buffer
  • params (string): Space-separated key=value parameters. Supported parameters include quad_segs, endcap, join, mitre_limit, and side. These parameters are identical to the PostGIS buffer parameter strings.

docs.title: ST_ClosestPoint

docs.title: Usage

geometry ST_ClosestPoint(geomA: geometry, geomB: geometry)
geography ST_ClosestPoint(geogA: geography, geogB: geography)

docs.title: Arguments
docs.text:
• geogA (geography): Input geography
  • geogB (geography): Input geography
  • geomA (geometry): Input geometry
  • geomB (geometry): Input geometry

docs.title: ST_Collect_Agg
docs.text: Combines multiple geometries from a set of rows into a single collection.

docs.title: Description
docs.text: An aggregate function that collects multiple geometries into a single GeometryCollection or the appropriate Multi-type if all inputs share the same geometry type.

docs.title: ST_ConcaveHull
docs.text: Returns a concave hull enclosing the input geometry.

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Returns a concave hull enclosing the input geometry. The pct_convex parameter controls how “tight” the hull is: 1.0 produces the convex hull, while smaller values produce tighter, more concave shapes.

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Returns true if no points of B lie outside A and at least one point of B lies inside A.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
SELECT ST_Contains(
    ST_GeomFromText('POLYGON ((0 0, 1 0, 1 1, 0 1, 0 0))'),
    ST_Point(0.25, 0.25)
) AS val;

┌─────────┐
│   val   │
│ boolean │
╞═════════╡
│ true    │
└─────────┘

docs.title: ST_ConvexHull
docs.text: Returns the Convex Hull of polygon A.

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Returns the smallest convex polygon that encloses all points in the input geometry.

docs.title: ST_CoveredBy
docs.text: Returns true if geomA is covered by geomB.

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Returns true if no point in geometry A is outside geometry B. Inverse of ST_Covers: ST_CoveredBy(A, B) is equivalent to ST_Covers(B, A).

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Returns true if no point in geometry B is outside geometry A. Similar to ST_Contains but does not require interior intersection.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
SELECT ST_Covers(
    ST_GeomFromText('POLYGON ((0 0, 1 0, 1 1, 0 1, 0 0))'),
    ST_Point(0.25, 0.25)
) AS val;

┌─────────┐
│   val   │
│ boolean │
╞═════════╡
│ true    │
└─────────┘

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Returns true if the two geometries have some (but not all) interior points in common and the dimension of the intersection is less than that of either input.

docs.title: ST_CRS
docs.text: Returns the Coordinate Reference System (CRS) metadata associated with a geometry or geography object.

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Returns the CRS (Coordinate Reference System) string associated with a geometry or geography. This is abbreviated as an authority/code if possible (e.g., 'EPSG:3857').

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
SELECT ST_CRS(ST_Point(0.25, 0.25, 4326)) AS crs_info;

┌───────────┐
│  crs_info │
│    utf8   │
╞═══════════╡
│ OGC:CRS84 │
└───────────┘

docs.title: ST_Difference
docs.text: Computes the difference between geomA and geomB.

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Returns the part of geometry A that does not intersect with geometry B.

docs.title: Description
docs.text:
Returns the inherent dimension of the geometry:

  • 0 for points or multipoints
  • 1 for linestring or multilinestrings
  • 2 for polygons or multipolygons

For geometry collections, returns the largest dimension among the components.

docs.title: ST_Disjoint
docs.text: Returns true if geomA is disjoint from geomB.

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Returns true if the two geometries do not share any points. This is the inverse of ST_Intersects.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
SELECT ST_Disjoint(
    ST_Point(0.25, 0.25),
    ST_GeomFromText('POLYGON ((0 0, 1 0, 0 1, 0 0))')
) AS val;

┌─────────┐
│   val   │
│ boolean │
╞═════════╡
│ false   │
└─────────┘

docs.title: ST_Distance
docs.text: Returns the distance between two geometries or geographies.

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Returns the 2D Cartesian (planar) distance between two geometries, in the units of the coordinate reference system. For geographic distance calculations, use ST_DistanceSphere or ST_DistanceSpheroid.

docs.title: Description
docs.text: If the geometry is simple it returns the geometry itself, if the geometry is collection or multi it returns record for each of collection components.

docs.title: ST_DWithin
docs.text: Returns true if two geometries are within a specified distance of each other.

docs.title: Usage
docs.text: boolean ST_DWithin(geomA: geometry, geomB: geometry, distance: double)

docs.title: ST_Envelope
docs.text: Returns the bounding box (envelope) of a geometry as a new geometry.

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Returns the minimum axis-aligned bounding box of a geometry. This is usually a polygon but can be a linestring for perfectly vertical or horizontal input.

docs.title: ST_Envelope_Agg
docs.text: An aggregate function that returns the collective bounding box (envelope) of a set of geometries.

docs.title: Description
docs.text: An aggregate function that computes the collective bounding box (envelope) of all geometries in a group.

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Returns true if the two geometries are topologically equal (i.e., they represent the same point set, regardless of vertex order).

docs.title: ST_FlipCoordinates
docs.text: Returns a new geometry with the X and Y coordinates of each vertex swapped.

docs.title: ST_Force2D
docs.text: Forces a geometry into a XY coordinate model.

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Discards any Z and M values present (if any).

geometry ST_Force3D(geom: geometry)
geometry ST_Force3D(geom: geometry, z: double)

docs.title: Description

docs.title: Usage

geography ST_GeogFromWKT(wkt: string)
geography ST_GeogFromWKT(wkt: string, srid: integer)

docs.title: ST_GeogPoint
docs.text: Creates a geography POINT from given longitude and latitude coordinates.

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Creates a geography Point from longitude and latitude coordinates.

docs.title: ST_GeometryN
docs.text: Returns the 0-based Nth geometry if the geometry is a GEOMETRYCOLLECTION, (MULTI)POINT, (MULTI)LINESTRING, MULTICURVE or (MULTI)POLYGON.

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Returns NULL if the index is out of range.

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Returns the OGC geometry type name prefixed with ST_. Possible return values include: 'ST_Point', 'ST_LineString', 'ST_Polygon', 'ST_MultiPoint', 'ST_MultiLineString', 'ST_MultiPolygon', and 'ST_GeometryCollection'.

docs.title: ST_GeomFromEWKB
docs.text: Constructs a geometry from Extended Well-Known Binary (EWKB).

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Parses an EWKB binary value and returns a geometry. EWKB extends the WKB format to include SRID information in the binary header and is useful for PostGIS compatibility.

docs.title: ST_GeomFromEWKT
docs.text: Constructs a geometry from Extended Well-Known Text (EWKT).

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Parses an EWKT string in the format SRID=<srid>;<wkt> and returns a geometry with the embedded SRID set. EWKT is used by PostGIS and other systems for human-readable output when an item-level SRID required.

docs.title: Usage
docs.text:
geometry ST_GeomFromWKB(wkb: binary)
geometry ST_GeomFromWKB(wkb: binary, srid: crs)

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Parses a WKB binary value and returns a geometry. The input is validated by default. An optional SRID or CRS can be provided as a second argument.

docs.title: Usage
docs.text:
geometry ST_GeomFromWKT(wkt: string)
geometry ST_GeomFromWKT(wkt: string, srid: crs)

docs.title: Description
docs.text: An optional SRID or CRS can be provided as a second argument to set the spatial reference.

docs.title: ST_HasM
docs.text: Returns true if the geometry has a M dimension.

docs.title: ST_HasZ
docs.text: Returns true if the geometry has a Z dimension.

docs.title: ST_Intersection
docs.text: Computes the intersection of two geometries or geographies.

docs.title: Usage
docs.text:
geometry ST_Intersection(geomA: geometry, geomB: geometry)
geography ST_Intersection(geogA: geography, geogB: geography)

docs.title: Arguments
docs.text:
• geogA (geography): Input geography
  • geogB (geography): Input geography
  • geomA (geometry): Input geometry
  • geomB (geometry): Input geometry

docs.title: ST_Intersection_Agg
docs.text: Returns the cumulative intersection of all geometries in the input.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
SELECT ST_Intersection_Agg(geom) FROM (
  VALUES
    (ST_GeomFromText('POLYGON ((0 0, 0 4, 4 4, 4 0, 0 0))')),
    (ST_GeomFromText('POLYGON ((2 2, 2 6, 6 6, 6 2, 2 2))'))
) AS t(geom);

┌───────────────────────────────────────┐
│      st_intersection_agg(t.geom)      │
│                geometry               │
╞═══════════════════════════════════════╡
│ MULTIPOLYGON(((2 4,2 2,4 2,4 4,2 4))) │
└───────────────────────────────────────┘

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
SELECT ST_Intersects(
    ST_Point(0.25, 0.25),
    ST_GeomFromText('POLYGON ((0 0, 1 0, 0 1, 0 0))')
) AS val;

┌─────────┐
│   val   │
│ boolean │
╞═════════╡
│ true    │
└─────────┘

docs.title: ST_IsClosed
docs.text: Returns true if the LINESTRING start and end point are the same.

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Returns true if the LineString’s start and end points are the same. For MultiLineStrings, all elements must be closed.

docs.title: ST_IsCollection
docs.text: Returns TRUE if the geometry type of the input is a geometry collection type.

docs.title: Description
docs.text:
Returns TRUE if the geometry type of the input is a geometry collection type. Collection types are the following:

  • GEOMETRYCOLLECTION
  • MULTIPOINT
  • MULTIPOLYGON
  • MULTILINESTRING

docs.title: ST_IsEmpty
docs.text: Returns true if the geometry is empty.

docs.title: ST_IsRing
docs.text: Returns true if a linestring is ST_IsClosed and ST_IsSimple.

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Returns true if the linestring is both closed (ST_IsClosed) and simple (ST_IsSimple). In other words, the input forms a ring with no self-intersections.

docs.title: ST_IsSimple
docs.text: Tests if geometry’s only self-intersections are at boundary points.

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Returns true if the geometry has no anomalous geometric points such as self-intersections or self-tangency.

docs.title: ST_IsValid
docs.text: Checks whether a geometry meets the rules of a valid spatial object according to the OGC standard.

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Returns true if the geometry is well-formed according to OGC rules. Use ST_IsValidReason to get a diagnostic message for invalid geometries and ST_MakeValid to attempt to repair them.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
SELECT ST_IsValid(
    ST_GeomFromText('POLYGON ((0 0, 2 0, 2 2, 1 1, 0 2, 0 0))')
) AS is_valid;

┌──────────┐
│ is_valid │
│  boolean │
╞══════════╡
│ true     │
└──────────┘

docs.title: ST_IsValidReason
docs.text: Returns a text explanation describing why a geometry is invalid.

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Returns a text string explaining why a geometry is invalid, or "Valid Geometry" if the geometry is valid. Useful for debugging geometry construction.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
SELECT ST_IsValidReason(
    ST_GeomFromText('POLYGON((0 0, 2 0, 2 2, 1 1, 0 2, 0 0))')
) AS reason;

┌────────────────┐
│     reason     │
│      utf8      │
╞════════════════╡
│ Valid Geometry │
└────────────────┘

docs.title: ST_KNN
docs.text: Returns true if geomA finds k nearest neighbors from geomB.

docs.title: Usage
docs.text: boolean ST_KNN(geomA: geometry, geomb: geometry, k: integer, use_spheroid: boolean)

docs.title: Arguments
docs.text:
• geomA (geometry): The geometry around which to search.
  • geomb (geometry): Column containing candidate geometries.
  • k (integer): The number of nearest neighbours to return.
  • use_spheroid (boolean): true to use spherical distance, false for Euclidean

docs.title: Description
docs.text: ST_KNN is used in a join condition to find the k nearest neighbors of one geometry from another set of geometries. The actual k-nearest neighbors logic is handled by the spatial join execution engine: the function itself is a stub that simply defines the expected signature.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
WITH table2 AS (
    SELECT geom1 FROM (VALUES
        (ST_Point(0, 1)),
        (ST_Point(2, 3)),
        (ST_Point(4, 5)),
        (ST_Point(6, 7)),
        (ST_Point(8, 9))
    ) AS t(geom1)
),
table1 AS (
    SELECT ST_Point(0, 0) AS geom2
)
SELECT * FROM table1 JOIN table2 ON ST_KNN(geom1, geom2, 3, false);

┌────────────┬────────────┐
│    geom2   ┆    geom1   │
│  geometry  ┆  geometry  │
╞════════════╪════════════╡
│ POINT(0 0) ┆ POINT(0 1) │
├╌╌╌╌╌╌╌╌╌╌╌╌┼╌╌╌╌╌╌╌╌╌╌╌╌┤
│ POINT(0 0) ┆ POINT(2 3) │
├╌╌╌╌╌╌╌╌╌╌╌╌┼╌╌╌╌╌╌╌╌╌╌╌╌┤
│ POINT(0 0) ┆ POINT(4 5) │
├╌╌╌╌╌╌╌╌╌╌╌╌┼╌╌╌╌╌╌╌╌╌╌╌╌┤
│ POINT(0 0) ┆ POINT(6 7) │
├╌╌╌╌╌╌╌╌╌╌╌╌┼╌╌╌╌╌╌╌╌╌╌╌╌┤
│ POINT(0 0) ┆ POINT(8 9) │
└────────────┴────────────┘

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Returns the length of geom. This function only supports LineString, MultiLineString, and GeometryCollections containing linear geometries. Use ST_Perimeter for polygons.

docs.title: ST_LineMerge
docs.text: Merges a collection of potentially connected line segments into the fewest possible LineStrings.

docs.title: ST_LineInterpolatePoint
docs.text: Returns a point interpolated along a line.

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Returns a point interpolated along a line. First argument must be a LINESTRING. Second argument is a double between 0 and 1 representing fraction of total linestring length the point has to be located.

docs.title: ST_LineLocatePoint
docs.text: Returns the location of the closest point on a LineString as a fraction of its total length.

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Returns a double between 0 and 1, representing the location of the closest point on the LineString as a fraction of its total length. The first argument must be a LINESTRING, and the second argument is a POINT geometry.

docs.title: ST_M
docs.text: Returns the M (measure) coordinate of a Point geometry.

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Extracts the M (measure) coordinate from a Point geometry or geography. Returns NULL if the geometry has no M dimension or for non-point geometries.

docs.title: ST_MakeLine
docs.text: Creates a LineString from two or more input geometries.

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Creates a LineString from two or more input Point, MultiPoint, or LineString geometries. The function connects the input geometries in the order they are provided to form a single continuous line.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
SELECT ST_MakeLine(ST_Point(0, 1), ST_Point(2, 3)) as geom;

┌─────────────────────┐
│         geom        │
│       geometry      │
╞═════════════════════╡
│ LINESTRING(0 1,2 3) │
└─────────────────────┘

docs.title: ST_MakeValid
docs.text: Creates a valid representation of an invalid geometry.

docs.title: Usage
docs.text:
geometry ST_MakeValid(geom: geometry)
geometry ST_MakeValid(geom: geometry, keepCollapsed: boolean)

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Collapsed geometries are either converted to empty (keepCollapsed=false) or a valid geometry of lower dimension (keepCollapsed=true). Default is keepCollapsed=false.

docs.title: ST_MaxDistance
docs.text: Returns the maximum distance between any pair of points in two geometries.

docs.title: ST_MinimumClearance
docs.text: Returns the minimum clearance of a geometry.

docs.title: Description
docs.text:
The minimum clearance is a metric that quantifies a geometry’s tolerance to changes in coordinate precision or vertex positions. It represents the maximum distance by which vertices can be adjusted without introducing invalidity to the geometry’s structure. A larger minimum clearance value indicates greater robustness against such perturbations.

For a geometry with a minimum clearance of x, the following conditions hold:

  • No two distinct vertices are separated by a distance less than x.
  • No vertex lies within a distance x from any line segment it is not an endpoint of.

For geometries with no definable minimum clearance, such as single Point geometries or MultiPoint geometries where all points occupy the same location, the function returns Double.MAX_VALUE.

docs.title: ST_MinimumClearanceLine
docs.text: Returns a LineString representing the minimum clearance distance of the input geometry.

docs.title: Description
docs.text: This function returns a two-point LineString geometry representing the minimum clearance distance of the input geometry. If the input geometry does not have a defined minimum clearance, such as for single Points or coincident MultiPoints, an empty LineString geometry is returned instead.

docs.title: ST_MMax
docs.text: Returns the maximum M (measure) value from a geometry’s bounding box.

docs.title: ST_MMin
docs.text: Returns the minimum M-coordinate (measure) of a geometry’s bounding box.

docs.title: ST_NPoints
docs.text: Returns the number of points of the geometry.

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Returns the total number of coordinate points in the geometry, counting all vertices across all components.

docs.title: ST_NumGeometries
docs.text: Returns the number of geometries in a geometry collection.

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Returns the number of Geometries. If geometry is a GEOMETRYCOLLECTION (or MULTI*) return the number of geometries, for single geometries will return 1.

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Returns true if the two geometries share space and have the same dimension, but are not completely contained by each other.

docs.title: ST_Perimeter
docs.text: Calculates the 2D perimeter of a given geometry.

docs.title: Description
docs.text: This function calculates the 2D perimeter of a given geometry. It supports Polygon, MultiPolygon, and GeometryCollection geometries (as long as the GeometryCollection contains polygonal geometries). For other types, it returns 0. To measure lines, use ST_Length.

docs.title: ST_Point
docs.text: Constructs a Point Geometry from X and Y.

docs.title: Usage
docs.text: geometry ST_Point(x: double, y: double, srid: crs)

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Constructs a Point geometry from X and Y coordinates. An optional SRID or CRS can be provided as a third argument.

docs.title: ST_PointM
docs.text: Constructs a Point with an M (measure) coordinate from X, Y, and M values.

docs.title: Usage
docs.text: geometry ST_PointM(x: double, y: double, m: double)

docs.title: ST_PointN
docs.text: Returns the Nth point in a linestring.

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Return the Nth point in a single linestring. Negative values are counted backwards from the end of the LineString such that -1 is the last point. Returns NULL if there is no linestring in the geometry.

docs.title: ST_Points
docs.text: Returns a MultiPoint geometry consisting of all the coordinates of the input geometry.

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Returns a MultiPoint geometry consisting of all the coordinates of the input geometry. It preserves duplicate points as well as M and Z coordinates.

docs.title: ST_PointZ
docs.text: Constructs a Point with a Z coordinate from X, Y, and Z values.

docs.title: Usage
docs.text: geometry ST_PointZ(x: double, y: double, z: double)

docs.title: ST_PointZM
docs.text: Constructs a Point with X, Y, Z and M coordinates.

docs.title: Usage
docs.text: geometry ST_PointZM(x: double, y: double, z: double, m: double)

docs.title: ST_Polygonize
docs.text: Builds a polygonal geometry from linear components in the input geometry.

docs.title: Description
docs.text:
Builds a polygonal geometry from linear components in the input geometry. Handles GeometryCollection and multi-geometries by extracting linear components. Typically used with collections of complete, simple linework that forms polygon boundaries.

Unlike many geometry constructors, this doesn’t require explicit closure of rings—any closed rings in the input will become polygon boundaries.

docs.title: ST_Polygonize_Agg
docs.text: Creates polygons from a set of geometries that contain linework representing the edges of a polygon.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
SELECT ST_Polygonize_Agg(geom) FROM (
  VALUES
    (ST_GeomFromText('LINESTRING (0 0, 0 10)')),
    (ST_GeomFromText('LINESTRING (0 10, 10 10)')),
    (ST_GeomFromText('LINESTRING (10 10, 10 0)')),
    (ST_GeomFromText('LINESTRING (10 0, 0 0)'))
) AS t(geom);

┌────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│                st_polygonize_agg(t.geom)               │
│                        geometry                        │
╞════════════════════════════════════════════════════════╡
│ GEOMETRYCOLLECTION(POLYGON((0 0,0 10,10 10,10 0,0 0))) │
└────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘

docs.title: ST_Reverse
docs.text: Returns the geometry with vertex order reversed.

docs.title: ST_Rotate
docs.text: Rotates a geometry counter-clockwise around the Z axis by an angle in radians.

docs.title: ST_RotateX
docs.text: Rotates a geometry around the X axis by an angle in radians.

docs.title: ST_RotateY
docs.text: Rotates a geometry around the Y axis by an angle in radians.

docs.title: ST_Scale
docs.text: Scales a geometry by multiplying ordinates with scale factors.

docs.title: Usage
docs.text:
geometry ST_Scale(geom: geometry, scaleX: double, scaleY: double)
geometry ST_Scale(geom: geometry, scaleX: double, scaleY: double, scaleZ: double)

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Scales a geometry by multiplying each coordinate by the corresponding scale factor. A 3D variant accepts scaleZ.

docs.title: ST_SetCRS
docs.text: Sets the Coordinate Reference System (CRS) for a geometry.

docs.title: Usage
docs.text:
geometry ST_SetCRS(geom: geometry, target_crs: string)
geography ST_SetCRS(geog: geography, target_crs: string)

docs.title: Description
docs.text:
Sets a CRS to a geometry/geography. This is metadata-only - no coordinates are transformed.

This is different from ST_Transform which actually transforms coordinates.

docs.title: ST_SetSRID
docs.text: Sets the SRID (spatial reference identifier) for a geometry.

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Sets the SRID (spatial reference system identifier) of the geometry. This is metadata only - no coordinate transformation occurs. Use ST_Transform to actually reproject coordinates.

docs.title: ST_Simplify
docs.text: Simplifies an input geometry using the Douglas-Peucker algorithm.

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Simplifies a geometry using the Douglas-Peucker algorithm. The tolerance parameter controls the degree of simplification: higher values produce simpler geometries. This function may produce invalid geometries; use ST_SimplifyPreserveTopology when validity must be maintained.

docs.title: ST_SimplifyPreserveTopology
docs.text: Simplifies a geometry, ensuring the result is a valid geometry with the same topology.

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Simplifies a geometry, ensuring that the result is a valid geometry having the same dimension and number of components as the input, and with the components having the same topological relationship.

docs.title: ST_Snap
docs.text: Snaps input geometry to reference geometry within tolerance.

docs.title: Usage
docs.text: geometry ST_Snap(geomA: geometry, geomB: geometry, tolerance: double)

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Snaps input geometry to reference geometry within tolerance. Result geometry aligns to the reference geometry where within tolerance distance.

docs.title: ST_SRID
docs.text: Returns the SRID (spatial reference identifier) of a geometry.

docs.title: ST_StartPoint
docs.text: Returns the start point of a linestring geometry.

docs.title: ST_SymDifference
docs.text: Returns the parts of geometries A and B that do not overlap.

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Returns true if the two geometries have at least one boundary point in common but no interior points in common.

docs.title: ST_Transform
docs.text: Transforms a geometry from one coordinate reference system to another.

docs.title: Usage
docs.text:
geometry ST_Transform(geom: geometry, target_crs: string)
geometry ST_Transform(geom: geometry, source_crs: string, target_crs: string)

docs.title: Description
docs.text:
Transforms the coordinate reference system of a geometry between EPSG reference systems. If provided with 2 arguments, target_crs can be specified as an EPSG code (e.g., ‘EPSG:4326’) or as a PROJ string.

When 3 arguments are provided, a source_crs can be used to specify the source CRS in case the input geometry doesn’t have an SRID defined. The source_crs takes precedence over the geometry’s SRID.

docs.title: ST_Translate
docs.text: Returns a geometry with coordinates translated by deltaX and deltaY.

docs.title: Usage
docs.text:
geometry ST_Translate(geom: geometry, deltaX: double, deltaY: double)
geometry ST_Translate(geom: geometry, deltaX: double, deltaY: double, deltaZ: double)

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Translates (shifts) a geometry by the given deltaX and deltaY offsets. A 3D variant accepts deltaZ.

docs.title: ST_UnaryUnion
docs.text: Returns a single geometry which is the union of all components.

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Returns a single geometry which is the union of all components of the input geometry. Useful for computing the union of a set of geometries stored in a single geometry (e.g., a GEOMETRYCOLLECTION or MULTI* geometry).

docs.title: ST_Union
docs.text: Returns a geometry that represents the point set union of two geometries.

docs.title: ST_Union_Agg
docs.text: Returns a geometry that represents the point set union of all geometries.

docs.title: ST_Within
docs.text: Returns true if A is completely inside B.

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Returns true if geometry A is completely inside geometry B. This is the inverse of ST_Contains: ST_Within(A, B) is equivalent to ST_Contains(B, A).

docs.title: ST_X
docs.text: Returns the X coordinate of the point, or NULL if not available.

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Returns NULL for non-point geometries or NULL input.

docs.title: ST_XMax
docs.text: Returns the maximum X coordinate of a geometry’s bounding box.

docs.title: ST_XMin
docs.text: Returns the minimum X coordinate of a geometry’s bounding box.

docs.title: ST_Y
docs.text: Returns the Y coordinate of the point, or NULL if not available.

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Returns NULL for non-point geometries or NULL input.

docs.title: ST_YMax
docs.text: Returns the maximum Y coordinate of a geometry’s bounding box.

docs.title: ST_YMin
docs.text: Returns the minimum Y coordinate of a geometry’s bounding box.

docs.title: ST_Z
docs.text: Returns the Z coordinate of the point, or NULL if not available.

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Returns NULL if the geometry has no Z dimension or for non-point geometries.

docs.title: ST_ZMax
docs.text: Returns the maximum Z coordinate of a geometry’s bounding box.

docs.title: ST_Zmflag
docs.text: Returns a code indicating the dimension of the coordinates in a geometry.

docs.title: Description
docs.text:
Returns a code indicating the coordinate dimension:

  • 0 = 2D (XY)
  • 1 = 3D with M coordinate (XYM)
  • 2 = 3D with Z coordinate (XYZ)
  • 3 = 4D (XYZM)

docs.title: ST_ZMin
docs.text: Returns the minimum Z coordinate of a geometry’s bounding box.
